page.title: 18Earthwork at Cattistock
page.content: On the north east side of Cattistock the ground rises sharply to about 600 feet to form a feature known as Castle Hill. Although it has not been excavated, there is enough evidence to suggest that people were living there from the Early Bronze Age. At the summit of the hill a four a half acre site is bordered by an irregular oval earth bank with ramped causeways on the north-east and north-west sides. In the enclosure is what is probably a damaged bowl barrow, 50 feet in diameter and four feet high. Outside to the north is a steep lynchet and to the east are banks and sinkings suggesting cultivation and huts from the later Celtic period. Wraxall also has several large round mounds suggesting the presence of Bronze Age bowl barrows.
